title:
Foliation of constant harmonic mean curvature surfaces in asymptotic
  Schwarzschild spaces

sections.text:
#### Abstract

This paper investigates the volume-preserving harmonic mean curvature flow in asymptotically Schwarzschild spaces. We demonstrate the long-time existence and exponential convergence of this flow with a coordinate sphere of large radius serving as the initial surface in the asymptotically flat end, which eventually converges to a constant harmonic mean curvature surface. We also establish that these surfaces form a foliation of the space outside a large ball. Finally, we utilize this foliation to define the center of mass, proving that it agrees with the center of mass defined by the ADM formulation of the initial data set.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

A spacelike timeslice has the structure of a complete Riemannian three-manifold with an asymptotically flat end in the description of isolated gravitating systems in general relativity. Thus, in this paper, we are concerned with the so-called asymptotically Schwarzschild space. Precisely, a complete Riemannian manifold $(N, \bar{g})$ is said to be an asymptotically Schwarzschild space, if $(N, \bar{g})$ is a 3-manifold where $N$ is diffeomorphic to $\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash B_{1}(0)$ and the metric $\bar{g}$ is asymptotically flat, namely,

$$
\bar{g}_{\alpha \beta}=\left(1+\frac{m}{2 r}\right)^{4} \delta_{\alpha \beta}+P_{\alpha \beta}
$$

where $r$ is the Euclidean distance, $m>0$ is a constant representing the ADM mass and $P_{\alpha \beta}$ satisfies

$$
\left|\partial^{l} P_{\alpha \beta}\right| \leq C_{l+1} r^{-l-2}, \quad 0 \leq l \leq 5
$$

with $\partial$ denoting partial derivatives with respect to the Euclidean metric $\delta$. For notation convenience, we in the sequel set $C_{0}=\max \left(1, m, C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3}, C_{4}, C_{5}, C_{6}\right)$.

The existence of foliation by special surfaces in an asymptotically Schwarzschild space is a significant problem in general relativity. The foliation offers an intrinsic geometric structure near infinity and provides a definition of the center of mass

associated with an isolated physical system. It defines a natural coordinate system near infinity which is extensively used in spacetime, see [CK93].

In their seminal paper, Huisken-Yau ([HY96]) constructed a foliation of stable constant mean curvature (CMC) surfaces in an asymptotically Schwarzschild space with $m>0$. These surfaces arise from the volume preserving mean curvature flow introduced by Huisken ([Hui87]). They also proved that the foliation is unique outside a large compact set depending on the mean curvature and defined the geometric center of mass based on their foliation. The uniqueness was further extended by Qing-Tian ([QT07]) saying that the foliation is actually unique outside of a fixed compact set, which we refer to as the global uniqueness. Corvino-Wu proved that the geometric center of mass of the foliation is the ADM center of mass if the metric is conformally flat at infinity in [CW08]. The conformal flatness condition later is removed by Huang in [Hua09].

Ye provided a different proof of the existence of CMC surfaces in [Ye96]. Metzger [Met07] later generalized Huisken-Yau's result to asymptotically flat manifolds with a slightly weaker asymptotic condition, namely, the metric $\bar{g}$ in (1) satisfies $\left|\partial^{l} P_{\alpha \beta}\right| \leq C_{l+1} r^{-l-1-\epsilon}, \quad 0 \leq l \leq 2$ for $\epsilon \geq 0$. However, the metric there should be assumed to be rotationally symmetric while the ADM center of mass can be defined for asymptotically flat manifolds satisfying the Regge-Teitelboim (RT) condition, which is interpreted as an asymptotically symmetric condition. Huang relaxed the symmetric assumption and proved that the CMC foliation exists in the exterior region of an asymptotically flat manifold satisfying the RT condition in [Hua10]. Nerz extended the existence and uniqueness of CMC foliation in 3-dimensional asymptotically flat manifolds without asymptotic symmetry in [Ner15]. Furthermore, the corresponding result was established by EichmairMerzger for dimension greater than three in [EM13]. Finally, we also notice that the global uniqueness of the CMC foliation is characterized by Chodosh-Eichmair in [CE22].

The CMC foliation is not the only foliation utilized in mathematical general relativity. For instance, Lamm-Metzger-Schulze establish the existence of a foliation of the asymptotically Schwarzschild space with positive mass by surfaces which are critical points of the Willmore functional subject to an area constraint in [LMS11]. The geometric center of mass of the foliation by the area constrained Willmore surfaces is also shown to agree with the ADM center of mass if the scalar curvature is asymptotically vanishing [EK22].

In this paper, we will establish a novel foliation by surfaces of constant harmonic mean curvature in an asymptotically Schwarzschild space with $m>0$. These surfaces arise from the harmonic mean curvature flow (HMCF), which has been investigated in the Euclidean space [DH06][DS10]. For non-Euclidean space, Xu explored the unnormalized harmonic mean curvature flow in his thesis ([Xu10]). More general mixed volume preserving curvature flows are investigated in Euclidean space in [McC05] and in hyperbolic space in [WX14].

Different from their attempt, we will examine the volume preserving harmonic mean curvature flow in asymptotically Schwarzschild spaces as a generalization of

Huisken-Yau's result [HY96]. To be precise, we first introduce some fundamental notion. Let $S_{\sigma}(0)$ be the coordinate sphere of radius $\sigma$ centered at the origin in $(N, \bar{g})$ given by a map

$$
\phi_{0}^{\sigma}: S^{2} \rightarrow N, \quad \phi_{0}^{\sigma}\left(S^{2}\right)=S_{\sigma}(0)
$$

We aim to find a one-parameter family of maps $\phi_{t}^{\sigma}=\phi^{\sigma}(\cdot, t)$ solving the initial value problem

$$
\begin{cases}\frac{d}{d t} \phi^{\sigma}(p, t) & =(f-F) \nu(p, t), \quad t \geq 0, p \in S^{2} \\ \phi^{\sigma}(0) & =\phi_{0}^{\sigma}\end{cases}
$$

where $F(p, t)=\frac{H^{2}-|A|^{2}}{2 R}$ and $\nu(p, t)$ represent the harmonic mean curvature and the outward unit normal vector of the surface $\Sigma_{t}=\phi_{t}^{\sigma}\left(S^{2}\right)$ respectively. Here we denote $\left|\Sigma_{t}\right|$ and $f(t)=\frac{\int_{\Sigma_{t}} F d \mu_{t}}{\left|\Sigma_{t}\right|}$ the area and the average of the harmonic mean curvature.

The flow described by equation (2) preserves the volume of the region enclosed by $\Sigma_{t}$ and $S_{\frac{\omega}{2}}(0)$. And we designate this flow (2) as the volume preserving harmonic mean curvature flow. It should be noted that, owing to the additional curvature terms, there is no monotonic quantity associated with this flow.

The first result of this paper establishes the long time existence and exponential convergence of the flow (2), which converges to a constant harmonic mean curvature surface.

Theorem 1.1. If $(N, \bar{g})$ is the asymptotically Schwarzschild manifold with metric (1), then there is $\sigma_{0}$ depending only on $C_{0}$ such that for all $\sigma \geq \sigma_{0}$, the volume preserving harmonic mean curvature flow (2) has a smooth solution for all times $t \geq 0$. As $t \rightarrow \infty$, the surfaces $\Sigma_{t}$ converge exponentially fast to a surface $\Sigma_{\sigma}$ of constant harmonic mean curvature $f_{\sigma}$.

Once establishing the existence of the constant harmonic mean curvature surfaces, we can further prove that they form a foliation of the asymptotically Schwarzschild manifold outside a large ball. For $\sigma \geq 1$ and $B_{1}, B_{2}, B_{3}$ nonnegative numbers, we now define a set $\mathcal{B}_{\sigma}\left(B_{1}, B_{2}, B_{3}\right)$ of nearly round surfaces in $(N, \bar{g})$ by setting

$$
\mathcal{B}_{\sigma}:=\left\{M \subset N\left|\sigma-B_{1} \leq r \leq \sigma+B_{1},|\hat{A}| \leq B_{2} \sigma^{-3},|\nabla \hat{A}| \leq B_{3} \sigma^{-4}\right\}\right.
$$

where $\hat{A}$ is the traceless part of the second fundamental form.
Theorem 1.2. There is $\sigma_{0}$ depending only on $C_{0}$ and $c=c(n)$ such that for all $\sigma \geq \sigma_{0}$, the constant harmonic mean curvature surfaces $\Sigma_{\sigma}$ constructed in Theorem 1.1 form a proper foliation of $N \backslash B_{\sigma_{0}}(0)$.

As a consequence, we are able to define the center of mass $C_{H M}$.

Definition 1.3. Let $\Sigma_{\sigma}$ be the family of surfaces constructed in Theorem 1.2 and $\phi^{\sigma}$ be the position vector. The center of gravity of $\Sigma_{\sigma}$ is defined by

$$
C_{H M}=\lim _{\sigma \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\int_{\Sigma_{\sigma}} \phi^{\sigma} d \mu_{e}}{\int_{\Sigma_{\sigma}} d \mu_{e}}
$$

where $\mu_{e}$ is the volume element with respect to the Euclidean metric.
Our last result in this paper shows that our definition of the center of mass agrees with the center of mass defined by the ADM formulation of the initial value problem for the Einstein equation, namely, the ADM center of mass.

Theorem 1.4. If $(N, \bar{g})$ is the asymptotically Schwarzschild manifold with metric (1), then $C_{H M}$ is exactly the $A D M$ center of mass.

The strategies of the proof for the main theorems follow the approach of Huisken-Yau ([HY96]) regarding the volume preserving mean curvature flow. More specifically, we initiate the volume preserving harmonic mean curvature flow (2) from a large coordinate sphere and provide the necessary a priori estimates of the second fundamental form together with the derivatives on the circular domain $\mathcal{B}_{\sigma}\left(B_{1}, B_{2}, B_{3}\right)$. However, there are several crucial innovations in our paper:

Firstly, in contrast to the volume preserving mean curvature flow, which is a quasilinear parabolic system, the volume preserving harmonic mean curvature flow is a fully nonlinear system. Consequently, this complicates the computations substantially. Secondly, the principal part of the linearized operator of the harmonic mean curvature $\mathcal{L}$ is not in divergence form. Nevertheless, it is not avoidable to give a priori estimate for the non-divergence elliptic operator $\mathcal{L}$ when proving the exponential convergence and the formation of foliation. In this context, we treat $\mathcal{L}$ as a perturbation of the Laplacian operator and furnish the estimate for the error term. Thirdly, in order to prove that $\Sigma_{\sigma}$ forms a foliation, we need to derive that the lapse function has a sign. Since the operator $\mathcal{L}$ is not self-adjoint, many useful tools in functional analysis and PDE cannot be applied. In order to obtain the desired estimate, we consider the sum of $\mathcal{L}$ and its adjoint operator $\mathcal{L}^{*}$, and establish the eigenvalue estimates for such a self-adjoint operator. Then we apply the elliptic estimate for such an operator to obtain the desired information.

Establishing the global uniqueness of the constant harmonic mean curvature foliation, as presented in Section 5 of [HY96] or [QT07], poses significant challenges. We will demonstrate uniqueness in our forthcoming paper, focusing on asymptotically flat manifolds with mild decay metrics or those satisfying the RT condition, as discussed in [Hua10]. Furthermore, we believe the harmonic mean curvature foliation is also applicable to asymptotically hyperbolic manifolds, as outlined in [NT09][NT10].

The subsequent sections are organized as follows: Section 2 provides some preliminary materials and evolution equations of geometric quantities for the volume preserving harmonic mean curvature flow; in Section 3, we give the proof of the long time existence and exponential convergence of the flow; the construction of the foliation and definition of the center of mass is treated in Section 4.

# 2. Preliminaries 

In this section, we present some fundamental concepts and also establish some useful lemmas. Let $\Sigma_{t}$ be a family of hypersurfaces in $(N, \bar{g})$ solving (2). Let $\nu$ be the outward unit normal to $\Sigma_{t}$ and $g$ be the induced metric on $\Sigma_{t}$. Denote the covariant derivative on $\Sigma_{t}$ and $N$ by $\nabla$ and $\bar{\nabla}$, respectively. Then for a fixed time $t$, we choose an orthonormal frame $e_{1}, e_{2}, \nu$ adapted to $\Sigma_{t}$ such that the second fundamental form $A=\left\{h_{i j}\right\}$ is given by

$$
h_{i j}=\left\langle\bar{\nabla}_{e_{i}} \nu, e_{j}\right\rangle
$$

Let $\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}$ be the two principal curvatures on $\Sigma_{t}$ and write

$$
\begin{gathered}
H=g^{i j} h_{i j}=\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2} \\
|A|^{2}=h^{i j} h_{i j}=\lambda_{1}^{2}+\lambda_{2}^{2} \\
F=\frac{H^{2}-|A|^{2}}{2 H}=\frac{\lambda_{1} \lambda_{2}}{\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}}
\end{gathered}
$$

for the mean curvature, the square norm of the second fundamental form, and the harmonic mean curvature on $\Sigma_{t}$ respectively. Furthermore, let $\hat{A}$ be the traceless second fundamental form such that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\hat{h}_{i j}=h_{i j}-\frac{1}{2} H g_{i j} \\
|\hat{A}|^{2}=|A|^{2}-\frac{1}{2} H^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{2}\right)^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

The curvature of $N$ together with the derivatives and the second fundamental form of $\Sigma_{t}$ are related by the equations of Gauss and Codazzi:

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{i j k l} & =\bar{R}_{i j k l}+h_{i l} h_{j k}-h_{i k} h_{j l} \\
-\bar{R}_{3 i j k} & =\nabla_{k} h_{i j}-\nabla_{j} h_{i k}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the index 3 indicates the $\nu$ direction. The derivatives of the curvature are related by

$$
\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 i j k}=\nabla_{l} \bar{R}_{3 i j k}+h_{j l} \bar{R}_{3 i 3 k}+h_{k l} \bar{R}_{3 i j 3}-h_{m l} \bar{R}_{m i j k}
$$

and the commutation of derivatives are

$$
h_{i j, k l}=h_{i j, l k}+h_{i m} R_{m j l k}+h_{j m} R_{m i l k}
$$

We should state another consequence of the Codazzi equation, which will be utilized in dealing with the curvature estimate, especially to handle the extra terms coming from the derivative of $F$.

Lemma 2.1. If $w_{i}=\bar{R}_{3 l i l}$ denotes the projection of $\bar{R} i c(\nu, \cdot)$ onto $\Sigma_{t}$, we have for any $\eta>0$ the inequality

$$
|\nabla A|^{2} \geq\left(\frac{3}{4}-\eta\right)|\nabla H|^{2}-\left(\frac{1}{4} \eta^{-1}-1\right)|w|^{2}
$$

Furthermore, we have the higher order version, for $k=1,2,3, \cdots$,

$$
\left|\nabla^{k} A\right|^{2} \geq\left(\frac{3}{4}-\eta\right)\left|\nabla^{k} H\right|^{2}-\left(\frac{1}{4} \eta^{-1}-1\right)\left|\nabla^{k-1} w\right|^{2}
$$

Proof. The first result comes from [Hui86]. To show the second statement, we first consider $k=2$ and then utilize induction argument. Similar to [Hui86], we define

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{i j k l}=\frac{1}{4}\left(H_{i l} g_{j k}+H_{j l} g_{i k}+H_{k l} g_{i j}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(w_{k l} g_{i j}-w_{i l} g_{j k}-w_{j l} g_{i k}\right) \\
F_{i j k l}=h_{i j, k l}-E_{i j k l}
\end{gathered}
$$

We find that

$$
\begin{gathered}
|E|^{2}=\frac{3}{4} H_{k l}^{2}-w_{k l} H_{k l}+w_{k l}^{2} \\
\left\langle E_{i j k l}, h_{i j, k l}\right\rangle=|E|^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, we conclude that $\left\langle E_{i j k l}, F_{i j k l}\right\rangle=0$. It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\nabla^{2} A\right|^{2} & =\left|\nabla^{2} \bar{A}\right|^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left|\nabla^{2} H\right|^{2} \\
& =|E|^{2}+|F|^{2} \geq|E|^{2} \\
& =\frac{3}{4} H_{k l}^{2}-w_{k l} H_{k l}+w_{k l}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies that

$$
\left|\nabla^{2} A\right|^{2} \geq\left(\frac{3}{4}-\eta\right)\left|\nabla^{2} H\right|^{2}-\left(\frac{1}{4} \eta^{-1}-1\right)|\nabla \omega|^{2}
$$

Next we state the Simons' identity of the harmonic mean curvature $F$ computed similarly as in [SSY75] and [BHMS99], and an important consequence of the Codazzi equations [Hui87] by considering $F$ as a function of $h_{j}^{i}=g^{i k} h_{j k}$.

Lemma 2.2. The harmonic mean curvature $F$ satisfies the identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
F^{k l} h_{i j ; k l}= & \nabla_{i} \nabla_{j} F+F^{k l} h_{i m} h_{m j} h_{k l}-F^{k l} h_{m k} h_{m l} h_{i j}-F^{k l} h_{k l} \bar{R}_{3 i 3 j}+h_{i j} F^{k l} \bar{R}_{3 k 3 l} \\
& +F^{k l}\left(h_{j m} \bar{R}_{m k l i}+h_{m i} \bar{R}_{m k l j}-2 h_{m k} \bar{R}_{m j i l}\right)+F^{k l}\left(\nabla_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}+\nabla_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right) \\
& -F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $F^{k l}(A) B_{k l}=\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial s}\right|_{s=0} F(A+s B)$.

Proof. Direct computation gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla_{i} \nabla_{j} F \\
= & F^{k l} h_{k l ; j i}+F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l} \\
= & F^{k l}\left(h_{k j ; l i}-\nabla_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right)+F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l} \\
= & F^{k l}\left(h_{k j ; i l}-\nabla_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}+h_{k m} R_{m j i l}+h_{j m} R_{m k i l}\right)+F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l} \\
= & F^{k l}\left(h_{j i ; k l}-\nabla_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}-\nabla_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}+h_{k m} R_{m j i l}+h_{j m} R_{m k i l}\right)+F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l} \\
= & F^{k l}\left(h_{i j ; k l}-\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}-\bar{\nabla}_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}+h_{k l} \bar{R}_{3 j 3 i}+h_{i j} \bar{R}_{3 k l 3}\right) \\
& +F^{k l}\left(2 h_{m k} \bar{R}_{m j i l}-h_{j m} \bar{R}_{m k l i}-h_{m i} \bar{R}_{m k l j}\right)+F^{k l}\left(h_{j m} h_{m l} h_{k i}-h_{k m} h_{m i} h_{j l}\right) \\
& +F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l}+F^{k l} h_{m k} h_{m l} h_{i j}-F^{k l} h_{m i} h_{m j} h_{k l}
\end{aligned}
$$

The underline part is disappeared since $F^{k l}$ is diagonal.
Now we calculate the evolution equations of the flow (2).
Lemma 2.3. We have the evolution equations along the flow (2):
(1) $\frac{\partial}{\partial t} g_{i j}=2(f-F) h_{i j}$,
(2) $\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \nu=\nabla F$,
(3) $\frac{\partial}{\partial t} d \mu=H(f-F) d \mu$,
(4) $\frac{\partial}{\partial t} h_{i j}=\nabla_{i} \nabla_{j} F+(f-F) h_{i l} h_{l j}+(f-F) \bar{R}_{3 i 3 j}$,
(5) $\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}=\Delta F-(f-F)\left(|A|^{2}+\bar{R} i c(\nu, \nu)\right)$,
where $d \mu$ is the induced measure on $\Sigma_{t}$.
Using Lemma 2.2, we can readily derive the following additional equations, employing a method analogous to that in [Hui87]. We denote the linearized operator by $\mathcal{L} f=F^{k l} f_{k l}$. It is straightforward to compute that $F^{k l} h_{k l}=F$.

Lemma 2.4. The second fundamental form satisfies the evolution equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} h_{i j}= & \mathcal{L} h_{i j}-(2 F-f) h_{i m} h_{m j}+F^{k l} h_{m k} h_{m l} h_{i j}-F^{k l} \bar{R}_{3 k 3 l} h_{i j} \\
& -F^{k l}\left(\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}+\bar{\nabla}_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right)+f \bar{R}_{3 i 3 j}+F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l} \\
& +F^{k l}\left(2 h_{k m} \bar{R}_{m j i l}-h_{j m} \bar{R}_{m k l i}-h_{i m} \bar{R}_{m k l j}\right) \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} H= & \mathcal{L} H-f\left(|A|^{2}+\bar{R} i c(\nu, \nu)\right)-2 F^{k l}\left(h_{m}^{i} \bar{R}_{m k l i}-h_{l m} \bar{R}_{m i i k}\right) \\
& -F^{k l}\left(\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 i k i}+\bar{\nabla}^{j} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right)+H F^{k l}\left(h_{m k} h_{m l}-\bar{R}_{3 k 3 l}\right) \\
& +F^{k l, p q} \nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla^{i} h_{k l}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \hat{h}_{i j}= & \mathcal{L} \hat{h}_{i j}+(f-2 F) \hat{h}_{m i} \hat{h}_{m j}-F H \hat{h}_{i j}+\frac{H^{2}}{4} F^{k l} g_{k l} \hat{h}_{i j}+\frac{f}{2}|\hat{A}|^{2} g_{i j} \\
& +H F^{k l} \hat{h}_{k l} \hat{h}_{i j}+F^{k l} \hat{h}_{m k} \hat{h}_{m l} \hat{h}_{i j}-F^{k l} \bar{R}_{3 k 3 l} \hat{h}_{i j}+f\left(\bar{R}_{3 i 3 j}+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Ric}(\nu, \nu) g_{i j}\right) \\
& -F^{k l}\left(\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}+\bar{\nabla}_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}-\frac{\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 m k m}+\bar{\nabla}^{m} \bar{R}_{3 k l m}}{2} g_{i j}\right) \\
& +F^{k l, p q}\left(\nabla_{i} h_{p q} \nabla_{j} h_{k l}-\frac{\nabla_{m} h_{p q} \nabla^{m} h_{k l}}{2} g_{i j}\right) \\
& +F^{k l}\left(2 \hat{h}_{k m} \bar{R}_{m j i l}-\hat{h}_{j m} \bar{R}_{m k l i}-\hat{h}_{i m} \bar{R}_{m k l j}\right) \\
& -F^{k l}\left(\hat{h}_{l m} \bar{R}_{m p p k}-\hat{h}_{m p} \bar{R}_{m k l p}\right) g_{i j}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial t}|A|^{2}= & \mathcal{L}|A|^{2}-2 F^{k l} h_{i j, k} h_{i j, l}-2 f \operatorname{tr}\left(A^{3}\right)+2 F^{k l} h_{m k} h_{m l}|A|^{2} \\
& +2 f h_{i j} \bar{R}_{3 i 3 j}-2|A|^{2} F^{k l} \bar{R}_{3 k 3 l}-4 F^{k l} h_{i j}\left(h_{j m} \bar{R}_{m k l i}-h_{k m} \bar{R}_{m j i l}\right) \\
& -2 F^{k l} h_{i j}\left(\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}+\bar{\nabla}_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right)+2 F^{k l, p q} h_{i j} \nabla_{i} h_{k l} \nabla_{j} h_{p q}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial t}|\hat{A}|^{2}= & \mathcal{L}\left(|\hat{A}|^{2}\right)+F^{k l}\left(H_{k} H_{l}-2 h_{i j, k} h_{i j, l}\right)+f\left(H|A|^{2}-2 \operatorname{tr} A^{3}\right) \\
& +2 F^{k l} h_{m k} h_{m l}|\hat{A}|^{2}+F^{k l, p q}\left(2 h_{i j} \nabla_{i} h_{k l} \nabla_{j} h_{p q}-H \nabla_{i} h_{k l} \nabla_{i} h_{p q}\right) \\
& +H F^{k l} \hat{h}_{k l}|\hat{A}|^{2}+2 f h_{i j} \bar{R}_{3 i 3 j}+f H \operatorname{Ric}(\nu, \nu)-2 F^{k l} \bar{R}_{3 k 3 l}|\hat{A}|^{2} \\
& -F^{k l}\left(2 h_{i j}\left(\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}+\bar{\nabla}_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right)-H\left(\nabla_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k j}+\nabla^{j} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right)\right) \\
& -2 F^{k l}\left(2 h_{i j}\left(h_{i m} \bar{R}_{m k l j}-h_{k m} \bar{R}_{m j i l}\right)-H\left(h_{m i} \bar{R}_{m k l i}-h_{l m} \bar{R}_{m i i k}\right)\right) \\
= & \mathcal{L}\left(|\hat{A}|^{2}\right)-2 F^{k l} \hat{h}_{i j, k} \hat{h}_{i j, l}-2 f H|\hat{A}|^{2}+2 F^{k l} h_{m k} h_{m l}|\hat{A}|^{2} \\
& +2 f \hat{h}_{i j} \bar{R}_{3 i 3 j}-2 F^{k l} \bar{R}_{3 k 3 l}|\hat{A}|^{2}-2 F^{k l} \hat{h}_{i j}\left(\bar{\nabla}_{l} \bar{R}_{3 j k i}+\bar{\nabla}_{i} \bar{R}_{3 k l j}\right) \\
& -4 F^{k l} \hat{h}_{i j}\left(h_{j m} \bar{R}_{m k l i}-h_{k m} \bar{R}_{m j i l}\right)+2 F^{k l, p q} \hat{h}_{i j} \nabla_{i} h_{k l} \nabla_{j} h_{p q}
\end{aligned}
$$

# 3. LONG TIME EXISTENCE AND EXPONENTIAL CONVERGENCE 

In this section, we show the long time existence and expoential convergence of the flow (2). We begin by recalling the following description of round surfaces in $N$ presented in [HY96].

Proposition 3.1. (Proposition 2.1 of [HY96]) Suppose $M$ is a hypersurface in $(N, \bar{g})$ such that $r(y) \geq \frac{1}{16} \max _{M} r=: r_{1}$ for all $y \in M$ and such that for some

constants $K_{1}, K_{2}$,

$$
|\hat{A}| \leq K_{1} r_{1}^{-3}, \quad|\nabla \hat{A}| \leq K_{2} r_{1}^{-4}
$$

Then there is an absolute constant $c$ such that the curvature $A^{e}$ of $M$ with respect to the Euclidean metric satisfies

$$

# 4. The Foliation 

In this section, we prove the existence of the foliation by constant harmonic mean curvature surfaces. We begin by providing a sufficient condition that guarantees a family of surfaces form a foliation.

Lemma 4.1. Let $\Sigma_{\sigma}=\phi^{\sigma}\left(\mathbb{S}^{2}\right) \hookrightarrow N$ be a family of surfaces parametrized by $\sigma \in\left[\sigma_{0}, \infty\right)$. In other words, for any $x \in N \backslash B_{2 \sigma_{0}}$, there exists some surface $\Sigma_{\sigma}$, for $\sigma>\sigma_{0}$ such that $x \in \Sigma_{\sigma}$. It is important to note that it is not true generally that the radial exponential map is a global diffeomorphism. And thus rather than proving the global diffeomorphism, we will prove that there exists a positive constant $\delta_{0}$ such that for any $i \in \mathbb{N}$, the map defined by

$$
\begin{gathered}

(t, p) \longrightarrow \exp _{p}^{N}\left(t \frac{\partial \phi^{\sigma}}{\partial \sigma}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}

\end{aligned}

& +\langle V, \nabla F\rangle-F^{i j, p q} h_{p q, k} h_{i j}\left\langle V, e_{k}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

We now conclude that the 1st variation of the $F$-operator with the constant harmonic mean curvature is given by

$$
d \mathscr{F}(\phi) \cdot V=-\left(\mathcal{L}+F^{i j} h_{j k} h_{i k}-F^{i j} \bar{R}\left(\nu, e_{i}, \nu, e_{j}\right)\right)\langle V, \nu\rangle
$$

where $\phi: S^{2} \rightarrow N$ is the embedding of the constant harmonic mean curvature surface. Define the operator

$$
L=-\left(\mathcal{L}+F^{i j} h_{j k} h_{i k}-F^{i j} \bar{R}\left(\nu, e_{i}, \nu, e_{j}\right)\right)
$$

This operator is then interpreted as the first variation of the constant harmonic mean curvature surface in the normal direction.

abstract:
This paper investigates the volume-preserving harmonic mean curvature flow in
asymptotically Schwarzschild spaces. We demonstrate the long-time existence and
exponential convergence of this flow with a coordinate sphere of large radius
serving as the initial surface in the asymptotically flat end, which eventually
converges to a constant harmonic mean curvature surface. We also establish that
these surfaces form a foliation of the space outside a large ball. Finally, we
utilize this foliation to define the center of mass, proving that it agrees
with the center of mass defined by the ADM formulation of the initial data set.
